content: The "Federal Government Spending Accountability and Oversight Act" establishes the Federal Government Spending Accountability and Oversight Commission to conduct surveys on cost control, review agency operations, and provide recommendations for improving management and reducing costs. The Federal Government Spending Accountability and Oversight Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various officials, with qualifications prohibiting government employees and requiring extensive experience in government spending and budget practices. The Federal Government Spending Accountability and Oversight Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various officials, with qualifications prohibiting government employees and requiring extensive experience in government spending and budget practices. Not more than 4 members appointed by the President shall be from the same political party. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Members can continue for up to 30 days if they become government officers or employees. Each member serves for the life of the Commission, and vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Federal Government Spending Accountability and Oversight Commission consists of 24 members appointed by various officials, with qualifications prohibiting government employees and requiring extensive experience in government spending and budget practices. Appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Members can continue for up to 30 days if they become government officers or employees. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, not later than 30 days after the vacancy occurs. Members serve without pay, with 13 members constituting a quorum for hearings. The Chairperson is elected by the members and serves for the duration of the Commission, calling meetings at least once per month. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Chairperson, who will determine the Director's pay rate. The Director can appoint staff with the Chairperson's approval, and their pay rate will be determined by the Director with the Chairperson's approval. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 6. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. Additionally, the Commission has the authority to enter into contracts. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, and devises of services or property to aid its work. Money and proceeds from sales of property received as gifts shall be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement upon order of the Chairperson. Accepted property is considered a gift to the United States for tax purposes. The Secretary of Commerce can collaborate on joint projects with the Commission under Public Law 91-412. Additionally, reports are required. The Commission is required to submit three reports to the President and Congress within specific timeframes after the enactment of the Act: a preliminary report within 6 months, an interim report within 12 months, and a final report within 18 months. The final report must include the Commission's findings, conclusions, and specific recommendations for legislative and administrative actions. In preparing these reports, the Commission must consider executive or congressional actions that can increase efficiency. The curr_chunk focuses on identifying opportunities for increasing efficiency and reducing costs in the Federal Government. It includes areas for enhancing managerial accountability, opportunities for managerial improvement, specific areas for potential savings, data on governmental expenditures, and programs that can be terminated or carried out more efficiently by the private sector. The term "Executive agency" is defined in this Act according to section 105 of title 5, United States Code. The expenses of the Commission will be paid from non-Federal sources, and the Commission will terminate within 30 days after submitting the required report under section 8(c).
